thread.title: Plans for tunnel under Stonehenge may be dropped
thread.title_full: Plans for tunnel under Stonehenge may be dropped

title: Plans for tunnel under Stonehenge may be dropped
text: comments Plans for a tunnel under Stonehenge may be dropped due to a £800million hole in the roads budget, according to England's transport watchdog. The landmark project is one of 112 schemes under review, with some posing a 'high risk' to public spending, the Office of Rail and Road (ORR) said in a report. Other projects that could be scrapped or delayed include plans to turn 13 miles of A1 in north of Newcastle into a dual carriageway, major upgrades to the M25, a new road near the Port of Liverpool and an upgrade to the A27 on the south coast. Plans for a tunnel under Stonehenge may be dropped due to a £800million hole in the roads budget, according to England's transport watchdog They were part of the £15billion makeover for England's roads, announced by Highways England in 2014. The schemes were all due to start between 2015 and 2020, but the ORR said poor-value projects could be abandoned and others delayed or downgraded, with work on some pushed beyond the initial deadline of the end of the decade.
